Problem:
Consider the system governed by the partial differential equation \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = \\mathcal{L}u\\), where \\(u\\) is a function of both space and time, and \\(\\mathcal{L}\\) is a linear differential operator. We explore the effect of applying a Fourier transform, denoted by \\(\\mathcal{F}\\), on the system and querying causality with and without intervention.

Observing the Fourier transformed system state \\(\\tilde{u}(t, k)\\) at time t, can one uniquely determine the initial Fourier-transformed state \\(\\tilde{u}(0, k)\\) assuming no knowledge of intervening transformations?
Explanation: Given the linear and time-invariant nature of the operator \\(\\mathcal{L}\\) in the Fourier domain, knowing the state at any time allows the unique determination of the initial conditions in the transformed \\(k\\)-space by reverse applying the exponential solution of the transformed differential equation.
